metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C String Functions
String Functions
C also has many useful string functions, which can be used to perform certain operations on strings.
content.html: C also has many useful string functions, which can be used to perform certain operations on strings.

content.text: To use them, you must include the <string.h> header file in your program:
content.html: To use them, you must include the <string.h> header file in your program:

content.code_html: #include <string.h>

content.text: String Length
For example, to get the length of a string, you can use the strlen() function:
content.html: For example, to get the length of a string, you can use the strlen() function:

content.code_html:
char alphabet[] = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ";
printf("%d", strlen(alphabet));

content.text: In the Strings chapter , we used sizeof to get the size of a string/array. Note that sizeof and strlen behaves differently, as sizeof also includes the \0 character when counting:
content.html: In the Strings chapter, we used sizeof to get the size of a string/array. Note that sizeof and strlen behaves differently, as sizeof also includes the \0 character when counting:

content.code_html:
char alphabet[] = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ";
printf("%d", strlen(alphabet));   // 26
printf("%d", sizeof(alphabet));   // 27

content.text: It is also important that you know that sizeof will always return the memory size (in bytes), and not the actual string length:
content.html: It is also important that you know that sizeof will always return the memory size (in bytes), and not the actual string length:

content.code_html:
char alphabet[50] = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ";
printf("%d", strlen(alphabet));   // 26
printf("%d", sizeof(alphabet));   // 50

content.text: Concatenate Strings
To concatenate (combine) two strings, you can use the strcat() function:
content.html: To concatenate (combine) two strings, you can use the strcat() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
char str1[20] = "Hello ";char str2[] = "World!";// 
  Concatenate 
  str2 to str1 (result is stored in str1)strcat(str1, str2);// 
  Print str1printf("%s", str1);

content.code:
char str1[20] = "Hello ";char str2[] = "World!";//
Concatenate
str2 to str1 (result is stored in str1)strcat(str1, str2);//
Print str1printf("%s", str1);

syntax_highlighting.text:
char str1[20] = "Hello ";char str2[] = "World!";// 
  Concatenate 
  str2 to str1 (result is stored in str1)strcat(str1, str2);// 
  Print str1printf("%s", str1);

content.code_html:
char str1[20] = "Hello ";
char str2[] = "World!";

// Concatenate str2 to str1 (result is stored in str1)
strcat(str1, str2);

// Print str1
printf("%s", str1);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
char str1[20] = "Hello ";char str2[] = "World!";// 
  Concatenate 
  str2 to str1 (result is stored in str1)strcat(str1, str2);// 
  Print str1printf("%s", str1);

content.text: Note that the size of str1 should be large enough to store the result of the two strings combined (20 in our example).
content.html: Note that the size of str1 should be large enough to store the result of the two strings combined (20 in our example).

content.text: Copy Strings
To copy the value of one string to another, you can use the strcpy() function:
content.html: To copy the value of one string to another, you can use the strcpy() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
char str1[20] = "Hello World!";char str2[20];// Copy str1 to str2
  strcpy(str2, str1);// Print str2 printf("%s", str2);

content.code:
char str1[20] = "Hello World!";char str2[20];// Copy str1 to str2
strcpy(str2, str1);// Print str2 printf("%s", str2);

syntax_highlighting.text:
char str1[20] = "Hello World!";char str2[20];// Copy str1 to str2
  strcpy(str2, str1);// Print str2 printf("%s", str2);

content.code_html:
char str1[20] = "Hello World!";
char str2[20];

// Copy str1 to str2
 strcpy(str2, str1);

// Print str2
printf("%s", str2);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
char str1[20] = "Hello World!";char str2[20];// Copy str1 to str2
  strcpy(str2, str1);// Print str2 printf("%s", str2);

content.text: Note that the size of str2 should be large enough to store the copied string (20 in our example).
content.html: Note that the size of str2 should be large enough to store the copied string (20 in our example).

content.text: Compare Strings
To compare two strings, you can use the strcmp() function.
content.html: To compare two strings, you can use the strcmp() function.

content.text: It returns 0 if the two strings are equal, otherwise a value that is not 0:
content.html: It returns 0 if the two strings are equal, otherwise a value that is not 0:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Compare str1 and str2, and print the result

// 
  Compare str1 and str3, and print the result

syntax_highlighting.text: // Compare str1 and str2, and print the result

// 
  Compare str1 and str3, and print the result

content.code_html:
char str1[] = "Hello";
char str2[] = "Hello";
char str3[] = "Hi";

// Compare str1 and str2, and print the result
printf("%d\n", strcmp(str1, str2));  // Returns 0 (the strings are equal)

// Compare str1 and str3, and print the result
 printf("%d\n", strcmp(str1, str3));  // Returns -4 (the strings are not equal)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Compare str1 and str2, and print the result

// 
  Compare str1 and str3, and print the result

For a complete reference of string functions, go to our C <string.h> Library Reference .
content.html: For a complete reference of string functions, go to our C <string.h> Library Reference.
